annotation.TEXT: Also, her boss theme is "Pure Furies" from Touhou. Why this is, I have no idea (if there's even some minor relation between Junko and Trance, then I have no idea what it is).
Murphy's Law of E-Tanks: If you use one, you won't end up needing it.

As hinted at before, Sound Dash is easily one of the best weapons in the game. It's essentially Comet Dash from Unlimited, but it's much faster, goes further, and has far more uses. However, it does have one significant drawback: While you're invincible to most enemies when using it, projectiles and explosions can still hurt you (which in turn, makes it almost useless against the boss who happens to be weak to it).

Since they don't show up anywhere else, I may as well point this out: Rembakuns (those bomb-dropping enemies from Napalm Man's stage) have some really wonky hitboxes in this game. Sometimes their lower halves are completely intangible, while the explosions they create aren't much better (which seems to be a reoccurring problem with some of these fan-games).

Mirage Man has a pretty simple pattern and gimmick (he'll create a clone of himself, though differentiating the two is easy enough). The problem is that if he boxes you into a corner, you can end up tanking his bombs without a way to avoid them. His weakness (the Sound Dash) doesn't help much either, seeing as you'll get hit by the explosions more often than not.
At this point, it's also worth mentioning that Trance has no weakness. The buster is the only thing that's even capable of hurting her, for that matter.

As far as the second set of Robot Masters go, dusting Sound Man first is the absolute top priority. His weapon, while somewhat flawed, still knocks the game's difficulty down by a significant margin. Best of all, he's weak to the Circuit Breaker (so there's no need to deal with any of the other RM's before taking him on).

With the first four Robot Masters out of the way, we now get a one-on-one fight with Trance. All things considered, she's not that difficult of a boss. She hits somewhat hard, but she has a pre-determined pattern that she cycles through every time. The only problem here is that if she gets you in a corner, there's generally no way to avoid getting hit when she starts doing her spinning attacks (jumping over her doesn't really work in that situation either).

The Mirage Bomb is the hardest hitting weapon in the game. Thankfully, it's also one of the better bomb-type weapons (as opposed to Hyper, Crash, Commando, etc). It can be remotely detonated, and it explodes on-contact with enemies. It's also this game's designated barrier breaker (which will be shown off in the next stage). The only downside is that it has rather limited ammo in comparison with some of the other weapons.

Haze Shield isn't completely worthless, but it's certainly one of the weaker weapons in the game. The shield portion has openings in it, which is always a bad thing (what's the point if a stray bullet has a chance of bypassing your defense?), while the splitting effect is too slow. The only positive thing about it is that it lets you jump much higher (which the demo sequence doesn't show off, for some reason).

Kunai Blade is the weakest weapon in the game (only dealing half the damage of a normal buster shot), but has rapid-fire features to compensate. It can also be aimed up or down as well (another thing that the weapon demo doesn't show off).

The upcoming section is basically littered with precision rising/falling via wind and spikes, immediately followed by a dick move with a fall into a pit (with fans and spikes on both sides). It's doable without any weapons, but that doesn't make it any less annoying. Circuit Breaker and Sound Dash are your best friends for avoiding any potential headaches here.

Trance Wrecker is almost like a hybrid between a heavy arcing weapon and a screen-clearer. Aside from dealing piercing damage, it also hurts every enemy on-screen when it hits the ground (the rumbling effect might be a bit much in the recording, though in-game, it's not nearly as bad).

If there's one enemy in this game that needs to be fixed, it's the Merserkers (flying axes). I'm half-way convinced that these things are actually ghosts, because they phase through objects and terrain at an almost constant rate.
